TopicTitle: Recommend scifi movies for people to watch

Articles.Content:
Especially if it's one other people are unlikely to have seen.

What makes them so good?

Primer.

I only know one person that's seen it, and that's because he's the one that told me about it.

It has that paradoxical sense of time travel to it, but it delves into its inherent problems and potentially universe-shattering side-effects.

No, it's not scientifically accurate, and a lot of the math is made up, but the accuracy isn't the point of the movie. I'd suggest watching it more than once if you enjoy it, just to understand it better.

Titan A.E. It's more 'Soft' Sci-fi but it has a good chunk of action and the 90's-early 00s animation style give it a vibe similar to treasure planet and Iron giant, the heyday of cartoons in my mind. Overall the movie was decent to good in reviews, but failed financially due to poor advertising. Bonus points for being on netflix now.
The two best Sci-fi movies(for me) are 2001 and 2010. They try to follow physics as much as possible and have some nice effects and miniatures.

Forbidden Planet is an oldie but goodie. Dated, but if you watch it you will discover where Gene Roddenberry cribbed many of the details you see in Star Trek. And the plot is based on Shakespear's The Tempest.

LOL I watched "Primer" for about three times, and I think each time I watched it, I shaved off 25% of totally not understanding what's going on. So perhaps after my fourth viewing I will finally get it

I didn't like Spaceballs. I thought it was just... really bad humour... I never quite got why people consider it the height of parody.

It's far from the height of parody, but it's also quite far from bad. The form of humour it uses is rather specific at times, though, so it's very much a polarizing film.

If I were to recommend one, it'd be Solyaris. It's an old Soviet film, and it's beautiful. It doesn't rely on heavy action or spectacular special effects, but on an interesting story and beautiful scenes. It's about a psychologist who gets sent to a station orbiting the planet Solyaris. The cosmonauts on the station have been going insane, it seems, so he's there to figure out why. It's psychological and thematic Sci-Fi, and I love it because of that. Hollywood did a remake somewhat recently, but the original is infinitely superior, as the remake didn't seem to understand what the original was about.

Ah, I know a good one. Stalker. It's based on the novel The Roadside Picnic by the Strugatski brothers. It is an old Soviet film. A lot of it is just slow scenes of landscapes and the group of three men moving through the abandoned countryside and dealing with 'the zone'. I find it a very difficult film to describe because you just have to see it to understand it. All I can say is that it is a very good film and definetly worth a watch if you're into slow, philosophical films.
